author: jgm
content:
> still on getAttesterDuties, (ref https://ethereum.github.io/eth2.0-APIs/#/Validator/getAttesterDuties)
> none of the fields are marked nullable, but my guess is the expectation of a validator that's exited would be you'll get the pubkey, then all nulls?
<@!680234424037670912> Yeah, a validator that is not attesting should return an entry with just the public key.

author: mpetrunic
content: Like you would do if validator doesn't exists at all

author: jgm
content: I suppose it depends on our level of user-friendliness in the return info.  If you're asking for keys a,b,c and you return info for keys a,c then it could throw clients that are expecting 3 entries, in order, for the three requested keys.

author: jgm
content: If we just want to return no entry for that key we can, but we should be explicit about this in the docs to ensure that users are aware they may be returned a different number of entries to that which they asked for.

author: paulhauner
content: I'm running 256 validators on an (imperfect) implementation of the standard API now. Finally!

author: .paulharris
content:
> I suppose it depends on our level of user-friendliness in the return info.  If you're asking for keys a,b,c and you return info for keys a,c then it could throw clients that are expecting 3 entries, in order, for the three requested keys.
<@!144468805697929216> i think some of the finer details are worth documenting, so we're aligned, previously we'd return a key with no duties, so i was assuming that, I like the thought of it being there still if we found it.
One 'weird' case is when you have asked for an out of bounds index in the list, currently i swallow it and return the valid ones. eg 64 validators but you ask for 1,14,60,65 -> you get back 1,14,60 and i internally log a debug trace for 65 being out of bounds
I'm not sold either way, option b would be to error out of the entire request...
